Assifuah repairs electical appliances and also sells electrical gadgets and parts in Elmina.  He has been engaged in this business since 2006. Assifuah uses his income to pay rent, utility bills and other financial expenses for his family. He is requesting a loan to purchase more electrical items to meet the increased demand from his costumers. The profits will be reinvested back into the business.

loans.use: to purchase more electrical items to sell

loans.name: Ben (L’Entente) Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq femmes du groupe Ben sont toutes mariées, elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans et 2 enfants vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier koko de la ville de Koutiala (région de Sikasso, république du Mali). Elles se sont  connues   à travers des liens   de voisinage et de travail.
Elles exercent presque la même activité d’achat et de vente  d’habits  et de chaussures. Elles sont très sollicitées dans cette activité. 
Afin  de satisfaire  le besoin de leurs clientèles qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe Ben a décidé d’intégrer  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son cinquième  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter des balles de wax en gros et une quantité importante de chaussures à Bamako (la capitale de la république du Mali). Les pagnes  sont vendus en détail, au comptant ou à crédit au marché de Koutiala et au niveau des entreprises. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen  de 140 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle, qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir aux besoins de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités.
 Elles ont pour ambition de diversifier leur commerce en embrassant d’autres activités génératrices de revenu comme achat  de réfrigérateur  pour les boissons.
texts.en:
The five women of the group Ben are all married - their average age is 32, and they have 2 children living in large traditional extended families in the Koko area of the city of Koutiala (in the Sikasso region in the Republic of Mali). They got to know each other through neighbourhood and work connections. They are all engaged in almost the same business: buying and selling clothes and shoes. They are highly sought after in this business. In order to meet the needs of their clientele, which never stops increasing, the Ben group decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso, a microfinance institution, with whom they are on their fifth group loan. All of their previous loans were repaid properly. They intend to use this loan to buy pagnes wax (a type of brightly coloured African clothing) in bulk and to purchase a significant quantity of shoes in Bamako (the capital of the Republic of Mali). The pagnes are sold at retail, either in cash or on credit, at the market in Koutiala and also to companies. They each hope to realize a monthly profit of 140,000 FCFA during this cycle, an amount which will be used to pay off the loan and to meet the needs of their extended family, with the remainder being invested in their businesses. They are planning to diversify their business by embracing other income-generating activities such as purchasing a refrigerator to store drinks.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and re-sell clothing and shoes

loans.name: Lidia Margarita

texts.es:
La señora Lidia C. se dedica a su actividad de venta de frutas y verduras en la ciudad de Managua teniendo su propio establecimiento el cual a diario busca la manera de como suplirlo de estos productos.

Actualmente ella se destaca por ser una excelente comerciante y es por esta razón que quiere superar en el negocio y para ello ha acudido a Ceprodel para ser beneficiada por un crédito para así comprar los productos y continuar en su actividad.
texts.en:
Señora Lidia C. sells fruits and vegetables in the city of Managua. She has her own establishment that she strives daily to provide with this produce. Currently she stands out as an excellent businesswoman because she wants to excel in her business. She has come to Ceprodel for a loan to buy produce so she can continue in her business.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of vegetables

loans.name: Argash

texts.ru: Юлдошев Эргаш житель Вахшского района. Возраст 40 лет , женат и имеет пятерых детей. Работает учителем в средней школе района. Кроме того занимается животноводством. Разводит крупно рогатый скот. Планирует получить кредит для того, чтобы  закупить комбикорм. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 5 месяцев.
texts.en:
Argash U. is a resident of Vachshkiy region. He is 40 years old, married, and has 5 children. He works as a middle school teacher. Besides his occupation in school, he has a business involving livestock. He breeds cattle. He plans to use the loan to purchase animal feed. Argash will be able to repay his loan within 5 months.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase animal feed

loans.name: Ishalla Kher Group

texts.en:
Mwanaisha has been a charcoal and firewood seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for ten years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $50. She works at her business every day. She is requesting her second loan from the Kiva field partner, BRAC Tanzania, so that she can buy more charcoal and firewood for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to expand her business, pay school fees for her children and save money for the future.  

Mwanaisha is forty-five years old, married, and has five children, ages twenty-four, twenty-three, nineteen, eighteen and thirteen. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Mkasi and Zainab. Each of these women have their own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood for her business.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace has owned a small grocery store in the Kihesa neighborhood of Iringa for six years. She belongs to the Semtema B south loan group (group code 2021). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $125. Every day, she works at her business for eleven hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more grocery items to improve her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Grace is 30 years old and married with two children who are ages 16 and 12.

loans.use: To buy more grocery items for her store.

loans.name: Areli

texts.es: Arelí tiene 29 años, es madre soltera y vive con su hijo de 2 añitos y su madre, en la casa de esta. Cuenta con una pequeña bodega en un espacio que le cedió su madre en su casa, donde vende abarrotes y otros artículos de primera necesidad. Con este negocio lleva un periodo de 8 años y atiende todos los días, de 7 de la mañana hasta las 9 de la noche. Lo que le gusta de su labor es que se siente útil y fuerte para sacar adelante a su hijo, sin la necesidad de una pareja irresponsable, nos menciona. Ella cree que su tienda es rentable porque cuenta con una clientela regular que consumen sus productos a diario. Para el futuro, Arelí quisiera tener un minimarket donde venda variedad de productos. Este es su 4to préstamo con MFP, y le gusta trabajar con su banco comunal porque todos son unidos, puntuales y responsables. El dinero que solicita lo invertirá comprando más productos para surtir su tienda.
texts.en:
Arelí is 29 years old and a single mother. She lives with her 2-year-old son and her mother in her mother’s house. Arelí has a small grocery store that she operates in a room in her mother’s house, where she sells groceries and other essential items. She has had this business for 8 years now and works there every day from 7 in the morning until 9 in the evening. What she likes about her work is that it makes her feel useful and strong in raising her son, which she does without the need of an irresponsible partner, she tells us. Arelí believes her store is profitable because she has a regular clientele that consumes her products daily. In the future Arelí would like to have a mini-market where she can sell a variety of products. This is her 4th loan with Kiva partner MFP. She likes working with her communal bank because everyone is united, punctual, and responsible. Arelí will use the money to invest in the purchase of more products so she can re-supply her store.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing her merchandise

loans.name: Maria De Los Angeles

texts.es: María de los Ángeles T. tiene 40 años, es madre soltera. Tiene 3 hijos a su cargo. La actividad económica de María es la venta de refrescos y compra de cosméticos y. Hace más de 2 años que se dedica a este negocio. Sus inicios se dan  porque necesitaba sufragar los gastos de su familia, además ella labora como conserje en un centro de salud porque con lo poco que gana aquí no cubre los gastos suficientes para cubrir sus estudios,  y decide establecer en su vivienda la venta de ciertos refrescos como pozol, cebada, tiste por lo que este negocio le ayudo mucho.  Además María sigue luchando por estudiar y salir adelante. El destino del financiamiento es para capital de trabajo para la compra de maíz, pozol, cebada y además en la compra de cosméticos como cremas, perfumes entre otros. El sueño de María es permanecer con ambos negocios ya que y obtener los ingresos necesarios para mantener a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Maria de los Angeles T., 40, is a single mother. She has 3 children, all of whom she supports. She operates a business buying and selling cold drinks and cosmetics. She's operated the business for more than 2 years. She started it because she needed a way to defray her family's expenses. She also works as a cleaner at a health center but the little that she earns there isn't enough to cover [her? the children's?] schooling and she decided to set up the business at home selling cold drinks such as pozol [a local drink made from cacao and maize], cebada [a local drink made from barley] and tiste [a local drink made from cacao]. Maria continues struggling to study and get ahead. The loan will be used to buy maize, pozol and cebada, as well as cosemetics. Maria's dream is to keep both businesses so that she can have the income she needs to support her children.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Rosa Adelaida

texts.es: La Señora Rosa Adelaida tiene la edad de 43 años, es madre soltera. Su actividad económica es ofrecer los servicios de costura. Hace más de 10 años que se dedica a este negocio. Rosa dio inicio a su negocio por sus padres ya que ellos le brindaron la educación para que estudiara cursos de costura, a Rosa le gusto mucho este oficio y su Mama le compro una maquina de coser para que ella trabajara en su hogar, es así que Rosa decide establecer este medio de vida en su hogar, su primer trabajo fue elaborar un vestido a una de sus vecinas y fue por ella que consiguió la fama para au trabajo se reconociera. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo para la compra de agujas, hilos, tijeras y telas para cortinas. El sueño de Rosa es que su trabajo sea el mejor y establecer una tienda con prendas elaboradas por ella misma.
texts.en:
Rosa Adelaida is 43 years old and a single mother. She earns a living as a tailor and has been doing so for 10 years. Rosa started this business with the help of her parents, who provided her with an education so that she could take sewing courses. Rosa really liked this type of a work and her mother bought her a sewing machine so that she could work at home. This is how Rosa decided to start to work in her home. Her first task was to decorate one of her neighbors' dresses and she thus became famous for her work. The loan she seeks is for working capital to buy needles, threads, scissors and materials for curtains. Rosa's dreams is for her work to be the best and to start her own store of manufactured garments.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Chong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Marcia Mireya

texts.es: La señora Marcia Mireya C. M. , tiene la edad de 37 años , habita en el barrio San Juan , ubicado en el municipio de la Concepción , junto a sus hijos , ella es madres soltera , los planes hacia su familia es poder ayudar a finalizar sus estudios a sus tres hijos , doña Marcia desde hace 15 años se dedica a la confecciones , la mayor dificultad que se le presenta es la falta de financiamiento , ella inicio con esfuerzos propios este negocio , los planes futuros hacia su negocio es poder comprar maquinas industriales . Con el financiamiento va a comprar materiales de confección para poder hacer sus vestidos y poder vender.
texts.en:
Marcia Mireya C. M. is 37 years old and is a single mother. She lives with her children in the neighborhood of San Juan, which is located in the municipality of La Concepción. Her plan for the family is to be able to help her three children complete their studies. Marcia has been in the clothing industry for 15 years. The greatest difficulty that it has presented to her is the lack of financing. She started the business on her own. Her future plan for her business is to buy industrial sewing machines. With this loan she will buy materials so that she can make her dresses and sell them.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabric, thread, buttons, and other items to be able to do her sewing work

loans.name: Norah's Group

texts.en: Noral T. is the leader of Kibyamirizi group in Mubende. She is fifty-six years old and a widow with seven children. She also cares for three orphaned dependents. She has been in the business of buying and selling maize and beans from Kizinga since 1989, and she is able to make profits amounting to about $100 a month. Norah intends to build her own house in the future. In order to stop paying rent, she also wants a building where she can put her store. She needs a loan to help buy more bags of beans and maize for resale.

loans.use: To buy maize and beans to sell.

loans.name: Villa El Carmen Group

texts.es: El grupo “Villa el Carmen” esta representada por la señora Segunda  y conformada por 12 miembros dedicados y con ganas de trabajar y salir adelante en sus pequeños negocios de venta de pan, pollo, ropa, abarrotes, carne y de servicio  y auxilio mecánico. La competencia a nivel comercial es alta pero la socias tienen mucha experiencia y saben como sacar adelante sus negocios ofreciendo productos variados y de buena calidad. El crédito que han obtenido, es para aumentar su capital de trabajo y emprender pequeños negocios para incrementar más sus ganancias, que se traduce en mejorar la calidad de vida de sus familias que día a día van mejorando mas, por ello están muy agradecidos por la confianza depositada para seguir trabajando con mas ganas. La socias van cursando su primer ciclo pero ya cuentan con experiencia en grupos solidarios por lo se comprometen a dar todo de si para salir adelante con responsabilidad y unidad.
texts.en:
The Group “Villa el Carmen” is represented by Sra. Segunda and consists of 12 members who are dedicated to succeeding in their small businesses. They offer goods and services such as bread, chicken, clothing, groceries, meat, and auto repairs. The level of business competition is high, but the members are experienced enough to know that they must offer a variety of high-quality products in order to get ahead.

The loan that they have received will be used to augment their operating capital so that they can continue their businesses and increase their earnings. This translates into a better quality of life for their families, which continues to improve gradually each day. For this reason, they are thankful for the confidence placed in them to continue striving for success.

The members are starting their first loan cycle together as a group, but they already have previous experience working with other solidarity groups. They promise to be responsible and cooperative with one another.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Bahia

texts.en:
Bahia is a hard-working woman. She has been working in agriculture for at least 20 years. She works with her husband in farming and her five kids help her after finishing their school work.

Bahia's family used to have land that depended on rain for irrigation. A few years back, they added one greenhouse on land that equals around half a "donum" (unit for measuring land). Now they have greenhouses over two "donum" and they plan to establish a new greenhouse with the help of this FATEN loan.

Bahia appears in the picture while planting her land.

loans.use: To establish a new greenhouse

loans.name: Ana María

texts.es:
Ana María es una madre de familia de 49 años de edad que vive junto a su esposo y sus 4 hijos a 10 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo, en el distrito de Pomalca.

Hace 2 años compró una fotocopiadora y la instaló en un pequeño ambiente de la casa de su padre que se encuentra en el centro de la ciudad, luego empezó a ampliar su negocio con la compra de golosinas, bebidas gaseosas y cosméticos para venta.

Este negocio es la única fuente de ingreso estable con la que cuenta su familia ya que su esposo trabaja como obrero eventual en la cosecha de caña de azúcar, el principal cultivo producido en el lugar.

Ella se encuentra solicitando por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1200 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en la compra de material para la fotocopiadora y además ampliar su negocio con la venta de útiles escolares.

Ana María planea comprar con las ganancias que perciba a futuro otra fotocopiadora y una computadora para trabajar haciendo tipeos y trabajos de investigación para los escolares de la zona, así planea ayudarlos y también apoyar a tres de sus hijos que aún se encuentran estudiando.

Ella es muy conocida por sus vecinos los que la consideran una mujer reponsable, emprendedora y que siempre está buscando la manera de sacar adelante a su familia.
texts.en:
Ana Maria is a 49-year-old mother that lives with her husband and 4 children, 10 minutes from the city of Chiclayo, in the district of Pomalca.

2 years ago she purchased a photocopy machine, and installed it in a small area in her father’s house located in the center of the city; she later began expanding her business with the purchase of sweets, soft drinks, and cosmetics to sell.

This business is the only stable source of income that their family counts on, given that her husband works as a seasonal laborer in the sugar cane harvest; this is the main crop cultivated in the area.

She is requesting for the first time from Edpyme Alternativa a loan of 1,200 PEN that she plans to invest in the purchase of materials for the photocopy machine, and also school supplies to sell and in that way expand her business.

Ana Maria plans on purchasing with future earnings another photocopy machine and a computer to type papers and research for the students of the area; in that way she will be helping them, and also supporting her three children that are currently studying.

She is well known by her neighbors and is considered to be a responsible woman, who is enterprising, and also is always looking for a way for push her family forward.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase school supplies to expand her business.

loans.name: Judith

texts.es: La señora Judith, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Cucardas II”, Distrito de La Banda de Shilcayo, Provincia San Martín, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 42 años y 03 hijos, 01 que aun dependen de ella y por lo que tiene que trabajar muy duro día a día.Su carácter emprendedor y el amor a su familia le motivaron a iniciar su propio negocio de Venta de Abarrotes que poco a poco fue aumentando y ganando experiencia en este tipo de actividad, haciéndose muy conocida y querida entre sus clientes.  En la actualidad tiene sus clientes fijos que a diario acuden a su bodega a comprar donde cuenta con todo lo que el ama de casa necesita y es quien personalmente les atiende  con alegría y entusiasmo. Con este préstamo de S/. 1,200.00, comprará arroz y azúcar en sacos, fideos en paquetes, leche y conservas de pescado en cajas y en variedad de marcas, huevos en javas y artículos de higiene personal para continuar dando una mejor atención a sus clientes. Judith, anhela ampliar e implementar mas su bodeguita y manifiesta que lo va a hacer realidad,  porque es una mujer que cuando se propone algo lo cumple. Agradece bastante al Movimiento Manuela Ramos, por apoyarla y apoyar a mujeres que quieren salir adelante.
texts.en:
Sra. Judith is a member of the Communal Bank “Las Cucardas II”, which is located in the District of La Banda de Shilcayo, San Martín Province, Deparment of San Martín. She is 42 years old, in a common law marriage, and has 3 children of whom 1 is still a dependent. Judith works extremely hard day after day. Her work ethic and love for her family motivated her to start her own grocery business. It has gradually increased as she has gained more experience. She is well-known and respected by her clientele. She currently has regular customers who come to her store to shop because it has all the products a housewife would need. Judith personally welcomes everyone with her cheerful and enthusiastic attitude.

With this loan of 1200 soles, she will buy sacks of rice and sugar, packets of noodles, milk, various brands of canned fish, crates of eggs, and personal hygiene products. This will help her continue to provide good service to her customers.

Judith hopes to expand and improve her small grocery store. She plans to make it a reality because she is the type of woman who completes what she sets out to do. She thanks the Manuela Ramos organization for their support and helping other women who want to get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase groceries to increase her inventory

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en: Dorothy is 40 years old and married with six children. She sells provisions and drinks very close to her house. She is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more provisions. She says thanks to all KIVA lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and provisions to sell

loans.name: Dama

texts.en:
Dama O. makes a living selling bread and tea, and has applied for this loan to buy fresh fish to cook and sell. She is 26 years old and married. Her husband is a soldier and they have two children, both of whom are in school. With the extra profits made possible by this loan, she hopes to be able to open up a resturant in a good location.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to buy fresh fish to cook and sell

loans.name: Nueva

texts.en:
Mrs. Nueva P. is married, 41 years old, and has five school-aged children. Her husband is a fisherman and they currently live at Lutao, Panaon, Misamis Occidental.

Nueva joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. 

Nueva is requesting a loan of 14,900 PHP as additional capital for her business. This will be her 9th loan from PMPC. Her husband’s income s not enough for their daily needs, especially if the weather is not good, so she is planning to use the loan to purchase additional items like manicure set, pedicure set, towels, nail polish, etc.

Nueva plans to expand her manicure/pedicure service into a parlor and wishes to see their family succeed in their chosen field of business.

loans.use: To purchase items for her manicure and pedicure business

loans.name: Von

texts.en: Von Y., 33, is a palm climber who has used his skill in tapping palm juice by hand for more than eight years. He also turns palm juice into palm sugar for sale, earning $3 per day to feed his family. Besides this, he and his wife raise a few pigs and cultivate rice for extra income. They have two young kids who are dependent on their income. Von Y. is taking out his first loan to buy more palm steps and palm tanks for his palm climbing business.

loans.use: To buy more palm steps and palm tanks for his climbing business

loans.name: Bendición Group

texts.en:
The women in this group use their loans to purchase varying items. Some use the money to buy lettuce, tomato, meat, bread, mayonnaise, oil and other items necessary for cooking pastries and meals to sell at lunch time. Others use it to purchase fabric, thread and buttons for making clothing, sheets and men's and women's garments. Yet others use their loans to buy soft drinks, wines, beer, lingerie, earrings, necklaces, chains and bracelets to sell.

Bendición Group was founded just two years ago with the help of another group that was working in the area. To date, members have learned to work together and meet deadlines, whilst bettering their business activities and helping each other with entrepreneurial advice. 

On average, each woman's loan is 537,500 PYG, which will be invested in the purchase of items to be sold in their respective commercial activities:

- Ceferina O. sells clothes. 
- Guillermina Ruiz D. sells ready-made food. 
- Mirtha R. sells clothes. 
- Joan J. sells drinks. 
- Mirian R. sells jewelry. 
- Juana J. sells ready-made food. 
- Luisa R. sells lingerie. 
- Sheila N. sells clothes. 
- Mirna M. sells clothes. 
- Barbara O. sells clothes. 
- Romina A. sells clothes. 
- Petrona C. is a tailor and seamstress. 
- Pabla J. sells ready-made food. 
- Mercedes G. sells clothes. 
- Eloisa G. sells ready-made food. 
- Lourdes Peña is a cleaning lady. 
- Estelvina P. sells drinks and cold beverages. 
- Andrea J. sells clothes. 
- Luisa J. sells clothes. 
- Antonia L. sells clothes. 
- Patricia V. is a hairdresser. 
- Lucia S. sells cosmetics. 
- Graciela V. sells clothes. 
- Mirian Z. sells cosmetics.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Ganbaatar

texts.en: Ganbaatar lives with his wife and three children in Uvs province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His two sons, aged 14 and 16, attend the local secondary school while the youngest, who is 1 year old, stays home with her mother. Ganbaatar operates a raw material  and meat trading business in his town. He sells animal skins, primarily sheep and goat skins during spring time. During winter, he mainly sells meat and meat products for which the price is higher than any other season. He started his business in 1997. Over the years, Ganbaatar has become quite experienced in raw materials trading and has built a stable operation. He is now planning to expand his business in the near future. Ganbaatar's business is very important to him and his family. He says, "All I want is to provide for my children's education and raise them to be good people." He is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (~1050 USD) loan to purchase sheep and goat skins to sell for his business.

loans.use: to purchase sheep and goat skins

loans.name: Virgenia

texts.en:
Mrs. Virgenia R. is from Lower Sto, Nino Mahayag, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 54 years old, married, and has four children. To make a living, Virgenia runs a hog-raising business. She has been engaged in this business for three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP per month from these activities.
Virgenia joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This loan was used to expand her piggery. Now, she is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new breeder hogs. This loan will be her fourth from PMPC.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase breeder hogs
